name: Kepler-150
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-150 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-150 is a star with 0.857 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.94 times its radius. It is located 2982.37 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-150 is known to have 5 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-150 b

Kepler-150 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.43 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-150.

The mass of Kepler-150 b is 1.66 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-150 b is 1.25 that of Earth. At 1.66 Earth masses, Kepler-150 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-150 c

Kepler-150 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.38 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-150.

The mass of Kepler-150 c is 22.05 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-150 c is 3.69 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-150 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

Kepler-150 d

Kepler-150 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 12.56 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-150.

The mass of Kepler-150 d is 11.30 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-150 d is 2.79 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-150 d is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

Kepler-150 e

Kepler-150 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.19 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 30.83 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-150.

The mass of Kepler-150 e is 14.72 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-150 e is 3.12 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-150 e is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

Kepler-150 f

Kepler-150 f was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 1.24 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 637.21 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-150.

The mass of Kepler-150 f is 21.41 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-150 f is 3.64 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-150 f is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-150, which contains 5 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
